dosimetry.constraints: Spinal Cord Max (Cumulative) < 50 Gy(RBE); Brainstem Max (Cumulative) < 60 Gy(RBE); Mandible Max < 70 Gy(RBE)
dosimetry.planNotes: Proton re-irradiation to maximize OAR sparing. Strict adherence to cumulative dose limits based on prior RT records.

fractions.notes: Patient relying on PEG tube for nutrition. Pain management regimen adjusted.

imagingAndReports.summary: Intensely FDG-avid soft tissue thickening and ulceration at left base of tongue (SUV 13.5). No other sites of disease.

reportDetails.findings: New intensely hypermetabolic focus within the left base of tongue / oropharyngeal region, corresponding to soft tissue thickening and ulceration on CT component (SUV max 13.5). This was not present on prior scans. No abnormal FDG uptake in cervical lymph nodes or distant sites.
reportDetails.impression: Findings highly suspicious for recurrent malignancy in the left base of tongue/oropharynx. No evidence of regional nodal or distant metastatic disease.

imagingAndReports.summary: Confirms enhancing infiltrative mass at left base of tongue/oropharynx, approx 2.5 cm.

reportDetails.findings: Enhancing, infiltrative soft tissue mass identified at the left base of tongue extending into the lateral oropharyngeal wall, measuring approximately 2.5 x 2.0 cm. This appears distinct from expected post-radiation fibrosis seen more superiorly in the tonsillar fossa. No suspicious cervical adenopathy.
reportDetails.impression: Enhancing mass at left base of tongue/oropharynx concerning for recurrent tumor.

reportDetails.diagnosis: SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA, MODERATELY DIFFERENTIATED, INVASIVE.
reportDetails.microscopicDescription: Sections show fragments of squamous mucosa with underlying infiltration by nests and cords of atypical squamous cells with keratinization and intercellular bridges. Mitotic figures are present. Findings are consistent with recurrent squamous cell carcinoma.
reportDetails.comment: Recurrent squamous cell carcinoma identified in biopsy specimen.

imagingAndReports.summary: IMRT 70Gy/35fx completed 2016. DVHs for critical structures obtained.

reportDetails.oarDoses: Spinal Cord Max: 44.5 Gy; Brainstem Max: 52.1 Gy; Mandible (Left) Max: 68.2 Gy; Parotid Gland (Right) Mean: 24 Gy
reportDetails.notes: Patient completed treatment course. Tolerated with expected Grade 3 mucositis, managed supportively.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Charles Davis (H&N Surgery)
progressNotes.summary: Pt referred for worsening throat pain 9 years post-CRT for tonsil SCCa. Exam suspicious for recurrence base of tongue. PET/MRI confirm. Biopsy performed -> recurrent SCCa. Discussed surgical salvage (high morbidity) vs re-irradiation. Refer to Rad Onc/Med Onc.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Maria Garcia (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt w/ recurrent SCCa L BOT/oropharynx s/p prior 70Gy IMRT. Reviewed case, prior RT records. Discussed re-irradiation options. Strong recommendation for proton therapy (IMPT) to maximize chance of delivering curative dose while respecting OAR tolerance. Plan 66-70Gy(RBE). Discussed high risk of severe acute toxicity (mucositis, dysphagia requiring PEG) and late toxicity (fibrosis, necrosis risk). Pt understands and wishes to proceed. PEG tube recommended pre-treatment.

progressNotes.author: Nutrition/Speech Path
progressNotes.summary: PEG tube placed. Swallowing exercises reviewed. High calorie/protein supplement recommendations provided.

progressNotes.author: Physics/Dosimetry
progressNotes.summary: IMPT plan finalized. Cumulative dose constraints met for spinal cord, brainstem. Plan achieves target coverage. Approved by Dr. Garcia.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Maria Garcia (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt completed 10 fx re-irradiation. Developing significant mucositis (Grade 2-3), pain managed with opioids. Using PEG for nutrition primarily. Tolerating setup. Continue RT with close monitoring/supportive care.

patientEducation.goalsDiscussed: Definitive re-irradiation with curative intent, acknowledging the high risks involved.
patientEducation.sideEffectsReviewed: High likelihood of severe acute side effects: severe mouth/throat sores (mucositis), significant pain, severe difficulty swallowing requiring PEG tube for nutrition, major fatigue, and severe skin reaction. High risk of late complications: soft tissue or bone necrosis, chronic swallowing difficulty (dysphagia), severe dry mouth (xerostomia), and damage to nerves or spinal cord.
patientEducation.safetyConsiderations: Aggressive pain management, meticulous oral and PEG tube care, monitoring for signs of infection or necrosis.
patientEducation.patientResponsibilities: Attend daily RT and frequent supportive care appointments. Communicate any changes in symptoms immediately. Maintain nutrition via PEG tube as directed.
patientEducation.medicationCompliance: Strict adherence to pain management regimen and any other supportive medications.
